The verse states:

The commentary states:

By this principle, birth has afflictions and karma as its cause, afflictions and karma have birth as their cause, and birth again has afflictions and karma as its cause. In this way, one should understand that the wheel of birth and death has no beginning.

This is clearly seen in sprouts and so forth, where there is the power of seeds and so forth, because of the determination of place and time. It is the same with fire and so forth as causes for cooking and so forth. Therefore there is no arising without a cause.
As for the assertion of a permanent cause, that has already been refuted above. Therefore birth and death definitely have no beginning.

This dependent origination is said to have four kinds in other places:

For example, a person, due to being defiled by craving and love, cuts off the life of a sentient being. This person, in one moment, has all twelve parts.

Here, delusion is called ignorance, the intention to kill is called action, the discernment of the various objects is called consciousness, the four aggregates that arise together with consciousness are called name-and-form, the pure faculties based on name-and-form are called the six sense bases, the combination of the six sense bases is called contact, the experience of contact is called feeling, this craving is called craving, the remaining upper-level afflictions associated with craving are called grasping, the two karmas of body and speech produced by them are called existence, the arising of such dharmas is called birth, the transformation is called old age, and the cessation is called death.

If this exists, that exists means if an event has conditions, cessation must exist.
If so, this event should not arise due to causes.

Because this arising gives rise to that arising.

Bhiká¹£us!

Next, what is the meaning of ignorance?

If so, it should be taken as ignorance that does not exist, because these two attachments are not appropriate.

As for the separate dharma, the verse says:

The explanation is as follows:
There are people who are the opposite of friends, and they are called non-friends as the antidote to friends, not as the remainder or non-existence of friends.

The other dharmas that can be the antidote to dharma, etc., are called non-dharma, etc., not the remainder or non-existence.
Non-illumination is also like this.
There is a separate dharma that can be the antidote to illumination, called non-illumination. How can this meaning be known?
Because it is said to be a cause and condition.
Moreover, it is said in a verse:
Because it is said to be a fetter, etc.
The explanation is as follows:
There are other sÅ«tras that say:

If it were only non-existence, it should not be said to have such meanings, and it cannot be established as the eye, etc., so there is a separate real dharma called ignorance.
In that case, just as one says a bad wife is no wife, and a bad son is no son,

The verse says:
Because it is not seen as bad knowledge.
The explanation says:
If you say it is not so, the meaning of blame is blameworthy.

It cannot be established that this knowledge is ignorance.
Why is this?
The verse says:
Because it is associated with views.
The explanation says:

Moreover, the verse says:
Because it is said to defile knowledge.ğŸ”½The explanation says:
The sutra says:
Because the mind is defiled by craving, it is not liberated; because understanding is defiled by ignorance, it is not pure.
If this is understanding, it should not become defiled understanding.
Just as there is a separate defilement of the mind that is different from the nature of the mind, namely craving and ignorance, so it is for understanding. Why not allow this?
Because good understanding is mixed with defiled understanding, therefore it is not pure, and thus it is said to be defiled by that.
This mind defiled by craving is said to be not liberated.
Is it definitely transformed by craving?
Because it is harmed by craving, it cannot be liberated. If one cultivates the antidote to the perfuming of craving, then it can be liberated.
In the same way, understanding defiled by ignorance is not pure. We analyze that understanding is not pure because it is harmed by ignorance.
If one wants to analyze, who opposes whom?
The masters say that ignorance is a separate category from knowledge, just like craving is from the mind.
If someone holds that all passions are ignorance, this view should be refuted by the above reasoning.
Why is this?
If ignorance is the general class name of all passions, then it should not be established as a separate passion in the meaning of fetters, etc.
If it is the same as views, it should not be said to be associated with views, because other passions are not mutually inclusive with views, etc.
It should also be said that the mind defiled by ignorance is therefore not liberated.
If you say this is said in order to distinguish differences, then ignorance should also be distinguished in wisdom.
We admit that ignorance is a separate passion. What is the nature of this ignorance?
Its nature is that of inability to understand reality, action, and fruit.
This is incomprehensible. What dharma is called inability to understand?

In either case, there are faults.
If there is a separate dharma called non-discrimination that is the antidote to discrimination, it is also incomprehensible.
Therefore, what is the nature of the dharma that is discriminated? Such categories are not non-existent.

If one further considers this, there would be many words to say, and therefore this discussion should be stopped.

Here, the teachers' wisdom arises in various ways.
Some teachers say:
But they also quote a sutra as evidence:
The sutra says:

Other masters say:

The six times six dharma gates.

Among the six contacts,

The five contacts of eye, ear, nose, tongue, and body are called obstructed contacts because they rely on obstructed faculties.
The sixth, mental contact, is called verbal contact.
Why is this?
Verbal means names, and these names are the long-term objects of mental consciousness.
Mental consciousness is called verbal, therefore mental contact is called verbal.
As a sutra says:
The eye consciousness only cognizes blue, it cannot cognize this is blue;
If the mental consciousness cognizes blue, it can also cognize this is blue.
The first contact is manifested by the support, the second contact is manifested by the object.

The mental consciousness arises verbally with regard to objects, not the five consciousnesses, therefore only this one is called verbal.
The contact associated with it is called verbal contact.

Moreover, these six contacts are further established as three contacts.

Illuminating, non-illuminating, and other contacts.
The commentary states:

Because it is associated with anger and greed, and also because it includes all.

At that time, how can two dharmas that arise simultaneously be established as that which produces and that which is produced?

But in this sÅ«tra, the mutual causality of contact and feeling is not accepted.

Moreover, this mind is associated with feeling. This feeling has a different object from the mind. How is this meaning established?
